column66: Do.you.have.any.further.comments.

It is rare that scientific results should be reproduced: too much effort not enough payoff!  Only if the results are of fundamental importance (which is very rare) in which case it is indeed done in any case.

The questions are not really relevant for my field of research. The data reproduced in my type of studies can never be precisely reproduced, only the overall patterns may be verified by redoing a study. Plots and statistical analyses can be reproduced.
no

The questions asked seem to be related to people who do more modelling work than I/we do. The equations needed to reproduce what we did are usually given in the paper, together with the measured data (at least in plots), as well as values for all parameters used, so some questions didn't make sense (I work in the laboratory on fundamental process understanding). Indeed, older papers (some decades old) often miss some crucial values to reproduce the results, but my feeling is that this has changed, anyway, in the field I work in. It might be different for larger scale models.

I agree that it would be nice to have fully reproducible results. However, I see lots of practical problems in actually realizing that:

- long-term storage of large low processing level observational data sets. We get many results from processing Terabytes of raw (Level0, Level 1) spectral data which is not in a publicly accessible data base (only the Level2 data product is).
- archiving a complete computing environment with a publication. I can see that people can provide virtual machines that run some scripts. But how would I provide the computing environment of a huge HPC system (which is replaced every 3-5 years) with a publication?
- the effort it takes to get something that runs on your local system to run on somebody else's system (even with VMs)
- the longevity of systems like Github which could be shut down any time for any reason.

My awareness about reproducibility issues has grown over the past couple of year. I am presently trying to switch to a more reproducible workflow. I agree with the reproducibility PI manifesto by Lorena Barba. I endorse the science code manifesto. I am a member of NumFOCUS.

Certain codes like those we use (NEMO) are very complex, and are run on large supercomputers. In these cases, re-running them would certainly be interesting but would require up to 20 million core hours. This is one limit of this reproducible principle (which is good anyway).

This sounds like a very interesting project. Maybe I could contribute by sending you some material and you could evaluate the degree of reproducibility of it. 
Do you already have a scale or metric of reproducibility of a paper?
I like the idea of making source code available via repositories such as git-hub, but sometimes there are restrictions on that, due to institutional policies or industrial partners.
Great survey, I hope it will open eyes!!

We (our lab in NOAA) are finally working on getting DOI numbers for our data sets.  I believe EBAS/NILU/WDCA is also working on DOI numbers for data submitted to them (we submit data to them and provide tools to our collaborators to submit their data to them as well).  I think DOI numbers are great but I worry about the existence of multiple identical data sets submitted to different archives (perhaps with different meta data based on institute/archive requirements) having different DOI numbers.  It seems critical to me that meta-data information include information on all of the archives that data have been submitted to and for a given data set indicate whether there is more than one DOI number that may represent the numerical data.

column5: I review papers submitted to journals
column66: Opening to the communities data sets used in papers is a huge need. Opening up source code raises IP problems.

I gave "middling" answers to the questions about my own practice. However, my way of working is now changing rapidly towards open access in all aspects including making all source codes and data sets publicly accessible, publishing data sets with a doi etc. Moreover, I am frustrated by the slow pace of change in the attitudes of scientists towards open access for data and codes. I am convinced that protecting one's data, and keeping one's codes secret, are simply bad practices that hinder tyhe progress of science and also that they are fundamentally incompatible with the receipt of public funds.
Great work
good luck - it all sounds excellent

The survey seems to me to be focused on numerical modelling and data analysis (availability of source codes and data). I think it would be interesting to adapt or broaden some of the questions for experimental work and theoretical work.

column5: I use scientific publications as part of the data corresponding to a scientific experiment in the frame of preservation programmes.
column66: I am participating as the science use case (space science) in the PERICLES FP-7 data preservation and reuse programme, your work interests me and I will contact you after I submit this survey.

Reproducibility is one of the most fundamental tenets in the sciences and every effort should be made by all involved in the scientific process (researchers, authors, editors, reviewers, societies, publishers, and others) to ensure that that goals is realized.

column5: I review paper, and edit them
column66: They way in which some of the questions are formulated make it more difficult to answer for the geoscience field.

I think the biggest obstacle to do what you describe is the TIME - normally our computational modelling behind a Scientific Paper takes many years to perform - it is thus not realistic for someone to repeat this if there is not funding for doing so. Instead we work in model inter-comparison projects and try to discuss similarities and differences between model results. I do agree that we lack behind and that this is not enough for scientific work to be truly scientific, but it's the only practical solution for now with the present funding conditions. I coordinate a EU funded project called PROJECT NAME where we currently address these issues in RESEARCH FIELD and we are about to launch a virtual water science Lab to increase transparency and stimulate collaborative projects using the same data and source codes. It would be nice to see if we can link out efforts between projects in some way?

column5: I review papers and serve as associate editor for two journals
column66: Best wishes for this research and your efforts in awareness raising about 21st century scientific method :-)

To be reproducible work does not need any access to code or data.  All code should be tested by each user to make sure it does what it says, and all methods should be described in each paper in sufficient detail to make them reproducible .... if one could, in theory, recreate work given the data etc that the author had then this is a satisfactory minimum.  Access to code, data etc .... is a bonus.  If the work could not, in theory, be recreated it is not science!

I have sent two of my papers to you by e-mail, which work to make geomorphology more transparent and reproducible.  The data underlying them (i.e. the modified DEM) are copyright, but the method is described so that work could be reproduced and tested if equivalent data were obtained and the method used followed.

Certain data types cannot be packed as appendix into a publication, e.g. field observations and documentation via drawings/photographs is in some cases difficult to do in 2D. However, where numerical data is available (also raw data), I'd appreciate it it would be fully accessible  to evaluate given results. 
There is a lot of pressure on publishing, especially in quantity. A fully open system to reproduce results, eventually mark (by the publisher on a community database) non-reproducible results might help to a) improve also the quality of research papers (especially given the fairly low scientific quality of many contributions in the most highly ranked journals in my field) b) prevent wasting time reading contributions just to realize that they might not be the most reproducible research (and everyone doing re-invents the wheel again).

column5: I act as reviewer and as editor

column66: Great survey! Very useful.

Well prepared questionnaire, some minor redundancies (see and download e.g., code is mainly "the same", right?), I strongly acknowledge any initiative for transparency, reproducibility, coherency in research and publications. What about integrating the topic of free and open software? "abolish" Matlab, use R ;)

Fingers crossed!

column5: everything that a scientists does, from reading, evaluating and writing proposals to teaching & evaluating students
column66:
interesting & important initiative, but it seems limited in its current scope, and with this in its method/approach.
The R-package is just one among many statistical tools/software, and not everyone uses it.
Reproducibility of plots, graphs, statistics is not the key issue; the problem is reproducibility of results, no matter what type of software and/or analysis tools are being used. For instance, in our field (geophysics --> seismology --> earthquake physics), there are many (large-scale, often HPC-enabled) codes for solving a specific problem (say, seismic wave propagation in heterogeneous media). The type of code, programming language, implementation, platform etc don't matter, as long as the physics is correctly represented (implemented) and the resulting time-series (or whatever output) are identical (within the numerical accuracy). Not every researchers has access to the needed computational facilities, but may choose a code that suits their hardware. Reproducibility is part of the chain "verification, validation, transparency" in science, and thus requires a broader context / approach.

Some of these questions seemed a bit simple, or only appropriate for simple models, not full scale general circulation models, for example. Especially since many are community models, and thus have the code already available if desired. The bigger question may the forcing than the code in many cases,

It seems important to note that source code availability is not a guarantee of reproducibility: the compiler used and its configuration are also important. This is a common problem when upgrading HPCs for example. So I think "reproducibility" should be taken broadly, i.e. in a semi-quantitative manner. 
Another obstacle to source code availability is licensing: developing a large numerical model, of the Earth System for example, represents a massive effort and investment, and it is normal to expect that some research institute will not allow their code to be distributed on a open-source basis.

Thanks for making this survey! You are touching such an important topic.

Kind regards,
